title: Pictured: Missing West Point cadet, 20, who vanished from the military campus with a rifle
text:
A West Point commander said: 'No cell phone activity in over 72 hours'

The missing West Point cadet is identified as Kade Kurita, 20, while crews are searching 6,000 acres around the school

A West Point cadet missing since Friday has been identified as 20-year-old Kade Kurita.

More than 130 additional soldiers from the 23rd Military Police Company were dispatched to help with the huge search Tuesday.

Kurita, member of Class of 2021, has been missing since he failed to show for a military skills competition Friday evening.

'There has been no cell phone or financial activity in over 72 hours,' Col. Cecil Marson, the West Point garrison commander, said in a Tuesday afternoon update.

'This leads us to believe that he is still in the vicinity of West Point.'

An M4 rifle is also missing, and West Point officials reiterated that Kurita may be a danger to himself but likely not to the public.

The West Point released added that he's not known to be carrying any magazines or ammunition.

Cadet Kade Kurita is pictured with actor Stephen Lang in this photo above

More than 130 soldiers have joined the search for Kade Kurita. The Cadet Chapel on the campus is seen above in a file photo

The Military Police began their search at 1am on Sunday morning before calling on the New York State Police and the Orange County Sheriff's Department.

Helicopters, drones and K-9 units have been involved in the search.

State police dive teams were using sonar to search the Hudson River and ponds near the campus, the New York Post reported.

In addition, soldiers and state troopers were also exploring more than 6,000 acres near West Point for any clues to Kurita's whereabouts.

West Point cadets march in a Pass-in-Review ceremony at the United States Military Academy, Saturday, Sept 21, 2019. The missing cadet (not pictured) failed to show up for a scheduled road march on Friday evening before the school launched an 'extensive search' which involved the deployment of helicopters, dog units and drones

'I want to thank the local and state law enforcement agencies and emergency services for their tireless support,' Lt. Gen. Darryl Williams, 60th superintendent of the US Military Academy, said in a statement.

The Army Criminal Investigation Division has opened an investigation concerning the missing cadet and weapon.

Bad weather hampered the search efforts Tuesday, but academy and New York State police as well as the MP company were continuing ground search efforts.

The West Point Military Academy, which houses over 4,000 cadets, is considered one of the best and most prestigious officer-training military academies in the world.

According to their website, the school's mission is to 'educate, train, and inspire the Corps of Cadets so that each graduate is a commissioned leader of character committed to the values of Duty, Honor, Country and prepared for a career of professional excellence and service to the Nation as an officer in the United States Army.'
description: The West Point cadet missing since Friday has been identified as Kade Kurita. An M4 rifle is also missing, but they don't think he has ammunition. Crews are searching more than 6,000 acres.
